section.heading: Argument of Francis X. Beytagh, Jr.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Number 829.
Mr. Beytagh, you may proceed.

turn.speaker: francis_x_beytagh_jr
turn.label: Mr. Francis X. Beytagh, Jr.
turn.text: Chief Justice and may it please the Court.

In view of the few minutes remaining to me, I'd like to turn first to the substance of the position of the Government which in essence says that the court below improperly determined that that the HEW regulation in question here conflicted with the statute.
If time permits, I should like then to have an opportunity to respond further to the jurisdictional point that Mr. Justice Stewart raised yesterday.
The statute that is in question here is Section 402 (a) 7.

It's reprinted in the Government's -- the appendix to the Government's brief in pertinent part, it provides that a state plan for aid and services to needy families with children must provide that the state agency shall in determining need take into consideration any other income and resources of any child or relative claiming aid to families with dependent children.
The HEW regulation construes that critical language any other income and resources as meaning actual income, actual contributions made by stepfather or a MARS.
California's approach is to the contrary.
They assumed that where there is a stepfather or a MARS that his income is attributable and is a resource of the child without any actual proof.
That's the essence of the controversy here.

Now, California agrees and the court below agreed that if HEW's regulation is valid, as a proper implementation of the act, that California's conflicting statute must necessarily fall in the sense that California can no longer continue to be entitled to receive benefits should the secretary determine to cut them off.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Under the Federal regulation, so I understand it, it would be incumbent upon California to prove or to show or to ascertain to its own satisfaction perhaps, how much in fact your stepfather or the man assuming the role of spouse actually does contribute.

turn.speaker: francis_x_beytagh_jr
turn.label: Mr. Francis X. Beytagh, Jr.
turn.text: That's -- that's correct Your Honor.
I think there are three positions that you could take, one is California which is essentially an irrebuttable presumption of support --

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Right.

turn.speaker: francis_x_beytagh_jr
turn.label: Mr. Francis X. Beytagh, Jr.
turn.text: From the very fact --

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: It's an attribution of support by what [Voice Overlap].

turn.speaker: francis_x_beytagh_jr
turn.label: Mr. Francis X. Beytagh, Jr.
turn.text: The other is an approach that could be regarded as consistent with the HEW regulation but I don't think it is, that is if the burden of proof is on the recipients to show that the income was not actually received.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Well, that's what I was --

turn.speaker: francis_x_beytagh_jr
turn.label: Mr. Francis X. Beytagh, Jr.
turn.text: But -- but our view is that the regulation -- the language of the regulation speaks in terms of actual contributions and income actually received and attempts to track King versus Smith in this respect, so I think that it's the third category which is that the burden of proof is on the state to show that the income was in fact received so as to reduce -- in extreme cases --

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: I suppose this might vary from months to months and even from week to week or even from day to day.

turn.speaker: francis_x_beytagh_jr
turn.label: Mr. Francis X. Beytagh, Jr.
turn.text: Yes, and California has raised the question that we think is reasonable question here about seriousness of the administrative burden.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: francis_x_beytagh_jr
turn.label: Mr. Francis X. Beytagh, Jr.
turn.text: Now, we have checked as best we can, HEW has checked on my behalf determined that some 40 states have programs that do exactly this, to track the HEW regulation.
I have attempted to ascertain whether the feeling of these states and their administrators is that that's a practicable way to proceed, and the answer has been yes.
It's not a complete survey but as best we could sample it.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Well, how do they deal with the fact this maybe a changing pattern?

I mean, the stepfather may have all good intentions and one month might contribute, the next month he might stop at bar and grill and drink up or gamble away all the money and not contribute that month.
What is the --

turn.speaker: francis_x_beytagh_jr
turn.label: Mr. Francis X. Beytagh, Jr.
turn.text: Most of them proceed as we proceed in the income tax context, they require self disclosure and self reporting.
Perhaps to the surprise of some, they've found that in most cases this works.
That people receiving welfare benefits are prepared and do disclose honestly what income they do receive from other sources.
This is the basic trust of President Nixon's welfare message, the notion of self reporting and self disclosure.
Besides that there are case workers that proceed to investigate and talk to these people.
They talk to the man and they talk to the women, whatever.
The problem there is very significant, there's no doubt about it but most of the states have not thought that they are insurmountable.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Do you know of any case in this Court where it has ever held, where two litigants have a controversy among themselves, there can be a case or controversy within the constitutional sense, when one of them has the right to settle the case on his own territory?

turn.speaker: francis_x_beytagh_jr
turn.label: Mr. Francis X. Beytagh, Jr.
turn.text: I'm not sure that I understand Your Honor(Voice Overlap).

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Well, the Government here has a right to decline that the state have money.

turn.speaker: francis_x_beytagh_jr
turn.label: Mr. Francis X. Beytagh, Jr.
turn.text: That's correct?

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: What's the case --

turn.speaker: francis_x_beytagh_jr
turn.label: Mr. Francis X. Beytagh, Jr.
turn.text: The Government is not a litigant in this case Your Honor.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: It's not a litigant but it's involved.

turn.speaker: francis_x_beytagh_jr
turn.label: Mr. Francis X. Beytagh, Jr.
turn.text: It's involved, that's correct.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: And that's what you try and decide.

turn.speaker: francis_x_beytagh_jr
turn.label: Mr. Francis X. Beytagh, Jr.
turn.text: But the litigation here --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: What should be a controversy between the Government and the state and the state can determine for itself whether it accepts the money.

turn.speaker: francis_x_beytagh_jr
turn.label: Mr. Francis X. Beytagh, Jr.
turn.text: Your Honor --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Why should that be a case of controversy which calls for the attention of this Court?

turn.speaker: francis_x_beytagh_jr
turn.label: Mr. Francis X. Beytagh, Jr.
turn.text: Well, Your Honor, I think that the controversy is between the people who consider themselves entitled under the federal statute.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: But they're trying to get around by -- around at all by saying, “Well, the state would do what it should, we'd get our money”.

turn.speaker: francis_x_beytagh_jr
turn.label: Mr. Francis X. Beytagh, Jr.
turn.text: Your Honor --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: The state doesn't have to do it.
The state can decline to do it and the Government can decline to that amount of money.

turn.speaker: francis_x_beytagh_jr
turn.label: Mr. Francis X. Beytagh, Jr.
turn.text: Well, the state can theoretically decline a debt but California like virtually every state has a specific statute that says that if any of their statutes and rules and regulations in the welfare context are inconsistent with Federal rules and regulations, the Federal rules and regulations shall prevail.
So, while theoretically California may be in a position to simply remove itself from the Federal program however impractical as a practical matter, they have made this judgment.
Their statute Section 11003 of the California Welfare and Institutions Code says exactly this.
We've checked other states statutes.
New York has even more explicit statute that says --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: But with reference to everyone out there.
The Government can settle it by not letting them have any money.

turn.speaker: francis_x_beytagh_jr
turn.label: Mr. Francis X. Beytagh, Jr.
turn.text: The Government can do this but --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: On its own.

Why should this Court with all the burdens it has multitudinous cases that are becoming before, undertake a case of controversy when there is not a case of controversy between the two main persons who are interested in this, namely the state and the Government.

turn.speaker: francis_x_beytagh_jr
turn.label: Mr. Francis X. Beytagh, Jr.
turn.text: Your Honor, I think Congress intended when it passed the Social Security Act for needy.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Social Security is a different thing.

turn.speaker: francis_x_beytagh_jr
turn.label: Mr. Francis X. Beytagh, Jr.
turn.text: This --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Why do you collect your money for social security?

turn.speaker: francis_x_beytagh_jr
turn.label: Mr. Francis X. Beytagh, Jr.
turn.text: This is a part of the Social Security Act enacted in 1935 as Your Honor knows and this AFDC program has been in existence since that time.
Congress intended I think it's quite clear.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: That's an obligation on the part of the Government, isn't it?

turn.speaker: francis_x_beytagh_jr
turn.label: Mr. Francis X. Beytagh, Jr.
turn.text: It's an obligation on the part of the --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Federal Government.

turn.speaker: francis_x_beytagh_jr
turn.label: Mr. Francis X. Beytagh, Jr.
turn.text: That's correct, to assist the state.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: This is an obligation to a certain extent on the part of the state, to certain extent on the part of the Federal Government under to be -- based on agreement which they can reach or not reach as they seek it.

turn.speaker: francis_x_beytagh_jr
turn.label: Mr. Francis X. Beytagh, Jr.
turn.text: But they've all seemed fit to do that and they all as we know is practical matter --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: The controversy here as to what the state can do and what the Federal Government can do.

turn.speaker: francis_x_beytagh_jr
turn.label: Mr. Francis X. Beytagh, Jr.
turn.text: Well, I think there's a very real controversy, these people --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: The Government has its own sanction in its own hand.
It can stop paying the state any money.

turn.speaker: francis_x_beytagh_jr
turn.label: Mr. Francis X. Beytagh, Jr.
turn.text: Well, in this particular case, these people claim benefits and the claimed that California --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Yeah -- yeah, right indirect claim benefit, you get a lawsuit settled between the state and Federal Government.

turn.speaker: francis_x_beytagh_jr
turn.label: Mr. Francis X. Beytagh, Jr.
turn.text: Well, Your Honor, I understand the difficulties with this Court not wanting to become the Court of last resort and welfare disputes.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Well, why won't this place us right there?

turn.speaker: francis_x_beytagh_jr
turn.label: Mr. Francis X. Beytagh, Jr.
turn.text: I don't think it will place you right there Your Honor.
It seems to me that if the law in this area is clarified so that the states understand the obligations they have and I think King versus Smith went a long way in that direction.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: If the states understand it, why should we have to decide it?

turn.speaker: francis_x_beytagh_jr
turn.label: Mr. Francis X. Beytagh, Jr.
turn.text: What I'm suggesting is that when cases like this are decided, it will be clear what the obligations of the states are.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: To that extent, but they change with these changing dates.
We need the changing litigants.

turn.speaker: francis_x_beytagh_jr
turn.label: Mr. Francis X. Beytagh, Jr.
turn.text: Well, Your Honor with all respect I don't think that the federal approach is changed the thing and so long as the Court establishes that the federal construction of the Act is the appropriate one in this area, then the state will necessary have to abide by it.
And I think California and New York and the other states have already made this judgment.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: We will have to abide by it, and if we don't the Government has its relief in its own hand.
It can decline to let him have the money.

turn.speaker: francis_x_beytagh_jr
turn.label: Mr. Francis X. Beytagh, Jr.
turn.text: That's correct but that's circular because they've already made this judgment unless California resends the statute, it's made a judgment that it will exceed to the Federal rules and regulations.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: And the Federal Government can at this moment withdraw its funds.

turn.speaker: francis_x_beytagh_jr
turn.label: Mr. Francis X. Beytagh, Jr.
turn.text: Correct.
And that's correct they can but whether that's a reasonable or practical courses would carry not just --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Probably more reasonable and to get this Court mixed status in every welfare case that arises in the whole range of this Court.

turn.speaker: francis_x_beytagh_jr
turn.label: Mr. Francis X. Beytagh, Jr.
turn.text: But the approach you suggest would carry over to every Federal matching grant program Your Honor and would simply say that there's no justiciable controversy here and that the way to proceed is for the Federal Government always to cut off funds and I don't think the Court has proceeded that way in the past and I don't think that it's a reason.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: We haven't had this case before.

turn.speaker: francis_x_beytagh_jr
turn.label: Mr. Francis X. Beytagh, Jr.
turn.text: Your Honor with all respect in King versus Smith, the Court said there is of course no question that the Federal Government unless barred by some controlling constitutional prohibition may impose the terms and conditions upon which its money allotments to the state shall be dispersed and that any state law or regulation --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: It is supported by this Court would deny that statement?

turn.speaker: francis_x_beytagh_jr
turn.label: Mr. Francis X. Beytagh, Jr.
turn.text: And that any state law or regulation inconsistent with such federal terms and conditions is to that extent invalid.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Yes, when it's raised in a case of controversy.

turn.speaker: francis_x_beytagh_jr
turn.label: Mr. Francis X. Beytagh, Jr.
turn.text: Well, I think that King versus Smith was as much a case of controversy as the present case.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Is there any --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: No, even if it was, there's no sign we should continue to be bound by if it's wrong.

turn.speaker: francis_x_beytagh_jr
turn.label: Mr. Francis X. Beytagh, Jr.
turn.text: No, I'm suggesting Your Honor that if the Court clarifies the questions raised in this case and other cases that there's no reason to expect that the Court will continue to be involved year after year in these disputes over the welfare law.
Once the secretary has his authority made clear, I think that it's reasonable for the Court to expect that he allied.
But there have been serious questions about this, they have been raised in litigation and they are before the Court presently.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: But the custom is now arrived whereby everybody bringing every kind of welfare case for this state bringing in a lap number of controversies that we are simply not capable on account of the lack of numbers, the lack of scope to handle.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: I suppose it's complicated somewhat for the fact that the statute is now amended and the regulations are amended.
And so, we'll have a whole new set of statutes and regulations to deal with this.

turn.speaker: francis_x_beytagh_jr
turn.label: Mr. Francis X. Beytagh, Jr.
turn.text: Well, I'm not sure that I'm clear on that.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: There are a new set of regulations of HEW are there not?

turn.speaker: francis_x_beytagh_jr
turn.label: Mr. Francis X. Beytagh, Jr.
turn.text: Well, there is not any new set of regulations there on the question here at issue --

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: How about the new California statute?

turn.speaker: francis_x_beytagh_jr
turn.label: Mr. Francis X. Beytagh, Jr.
turn.text: Well, the new California statute as Mr. Amsterdam discussed yesterday does raise with respect to parts of the controversy before the Court, some questions that have to be resolved I think on remand by the District Court but it doesn't do away with the entire matter here.
It doesn't touch the step father questions and California is continuing to act as far as we know under the old statute.
They have not yet promulgated regulations -- officially adopted regulations.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: When does the new statute go in to effect again?

turn.speaker: francis_x_beytagh_jr
turn.label: Mr. Francis X. Beytagh, Jr.
turn.text: Well, the new statute was enacted in November 1969 and we agreed that there are questions that properly should be probed as to that statute and its effect on the MARS, man assuming the role of a spouse because that's all that it relates to by the District Court and we suggest to that extent to the remand of that Court would be appropriate but that doesn't (Inaudible) --
Your Honor, I really have had a chance on behalf of HEW to make the affirmative argument and could I have several minutes to do so?

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: The affirmative argument on --

turn.speaker: francis_x_beytagh_jr
turn.label: Mr. Francis X. Beytagh, Jr.
turn.text: On the validity of its regulation.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: For how long do you think you'd need?

turn.speaker: francis_x_beytagh_jr
turn.label: Mr. Francis X. Beytagh, Jr.
turn.text: About five minutes.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: I will grant you five minutes and extend accordingly.

turn.speaker: francis_x_beytagh_jr
turn.label: Mr. Francis X. Beytagh, Jr.
turn.text: Thank you, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: We can trade on that.

turn.speaker: francis_x_beytagh_jr
turn.label: Mr. Francis X. Beytagh, Jr.
turn.text: We think that the regulation is valid for a number of reasons.

First, we think that the presumption of validity always attaches and as this Court has said a number of times to the administrative interpretation by a Government official charged with the responsibility for administering a particular act.

As Mr. Amsterdam indicated yesterday, the same approach, the approach of requiring proof of actual income before reduction of benefits has been applied across the board in other categorical public assistance programs by HEW.

Moreover, we think that in 1967 Congress at least implicitly approved the HEW regulation when it reenacted the Act and in an act of certain amendments to these provisions knowing what HEW's construction had been and not seeking to change it.

Moreover, we think that it's quite clear in King versus Smith, the Court specifically referred to predecessor regulation and said regulations of HEW, this is in footnote 16 of King versus Smith, regulations of HEW which clearly comport with the statute, restrict the resources which are to be taken into account under Section 602 to those that, "are in fact available to an applicant or recipient for current use on a regular basis."
This regulation properly excludes from consideration resources which are merely assumed to be available to the needy individual.

Moreover, the Court earlier this term summarily affirmed the decision by the Court -- the District Court in Connecticut in Salman versus Shapiro which is reported at 396 US file which held the HEW regulation valid and an inconsistent Connecticut practice to be invalid.
Moreover, we think that the HEW's approach is consistent with the purpose of the act which is to provide economic security to the five million plus children that are covered by this act.
It's a massive act.
This regulation is an important part of it.
The -- the whole program involves expenditure of over $2 billion by the Federal Government each year, a total expenditure close to $4 billion.

California statute we think conflicts with this regulation and since California has a statute that I already have referred to which says that when it's rules and regulations conflict the federal rules shall prevail, we think whatever the relevance of this supremacy clause that in this context the District Court improperly struck down the HEW regulation and improperly upheld the California approach.
California's approach of assuming support simply is contrary to fact in most cases.
Moreover, it is inconsistent with King versus Smith for the reasons that I've indicated earlier.

There's some language in that opinion that counsel might prefer to but that language is always accompanied by the reference to support in fact and while the Court referred to a legal obligation, it also referred to support in fact as coupled therewith.
The Court was referring King versus Smith, we think to a legal obligation of general applicability not the strange sort of thing that California sought to carve out.

Indeed, if California is right, Alabama could have avoided the decision there by just enacting a statute which said “Okay, substitute fathers have a legal obligation of support whether it was enforceable or not what difference it would have complied.”
Now, we don't think the Court intend to that King versus Smith.
We don't think that makes good sense.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: I think, he would followed from what California has done that the family would not be eligible for AFDC grants at all.

turn.speaker: francis_x_beytagh_jr
turn.label: Mr. Francis X. Beytagh, Jr.
turn.text: I think Your Honor, that's the ultimate conclusion that you reach here.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: You mean it would be the same as the situation in King and Smith.

turn.speaker: francis_x_beytagh_jr
turn.label: Mr. Francis X. Beytagh, Jr.
turn.text: That -- well --

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Because the families are eligible only if one parent is dead or absent.

turn.speaker: francis_x_beytagh_jr
turn.label: Mr. Francis X. Beytagh, Jr.
turn.text: That's correct.

If you pressed it to the ultimate they are making these people parents and by definition they're not eligible -- but California doesn't want that of course, because the statute we're talking about here is specifically tailored to AFDC and relates only to that context.

So, they are simply trying to reduce the benefits that people receive by assumed support they get from these men without any acts of proof of it, and I think that if California were pressed too, there are some state -- a couple of states have adopted statutes that at least as the stepfathers place a general obligation.
As to those we --

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: And that makes the family --

turn.speaker: francis_x_beytagh_jr
turn.label: Mr. Francis X. Beytagh, Jr.
turn.text: As to those we would agree.
Yes, and that's Washington adopted statute and I think a couple of our states.
That's quite right.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: You mean, if California had a general statute applying to the MARS that --

turn.speaker: francis_x_beytagh_jr
turn.label: Mr. Francis X. Beytagh, Jr.
turn.text: I couldn't really conceive one applied to MARS but stepfathers is a reason -- I think is a feasible thing as I indicated some states too.
And that makes the stepfather -- the regulation itself, the first part which I didn't read specifically provides that.

It says that born relation to a child's stepparent who is ceremonially married to the child's natural or adopted parent and is legally obligated to support the child under state law of general applicability which requires stepparents to support stepchildren to the same extent that natural or adopted are required to support their children.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: But why would you say that was alright?

turn.speaker: francis_x_beytagh_jr
turn.label: Mr. Francis X. Beytagh, Jr.
turn.text: Well, I think the judgment is that you have then a real and enforceable obligation that's analogues to the obligation of a natural or an adoptive parent.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Well, if the state can substantiate the fact that there's a legal obligation to support the children in the house, his living in the house there's a legal obligation under the state law to support those children and if it's enforceable you would say the state regulation is alright?

turn.speaker: francis_x_beytagh_jr
turn.label: Mr. Francis X. Beytagh, Jr.
turn.text: Well, it has to be one that meets all the criteria that this regulation spells out which is one of general -- the person becomes just as natural or adoptive father or stepfather.
Now, most of these people simply don't want to be put in that position and I don't think most states are going to adopt --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Well no, but when you say that that would be alright, what you are really doing is assuming income.

turn.speaker: francis_x_beytagh_jr
turn.label: Mr. Francis X. Beytagh, Jr.
turn.text: But your -- well yes, and just as you're assuming income as to natural parent --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: With a parent.
With their parent, with a natural parent living at home.

turn.speaker: francis_x_beytagh_jr
turn.label: Mr. Francis X. Beytagh, Jr.
turn.text: Right.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: And then the parent moves out you no longer assume income, do you?

turn.speaker: francis_x_beytagh_jr
turn.label: Mr. Francis X. Beytagh, Jr.
turn.text: No, that's correct.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: And but as long as he is at home you assume income.

turn.speaker: francis_x_beytagh_jr
turn.label: Mr. Francis X. Beytagh, Jr.
turn.text: That's correct.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Do you say you would be willing to assume income if the state had the proper law with respect to stepfather.

turn.speaker: francis_x_beytagh_jr
turn.label: Mr. Francis X. Beytagh, Jr.
turn.text: I think that that's a necessary conclusion, that's the way the regulation reads and for good or for bad, we have to support the regulation.
But I think that it coincides with the common sense.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: You think it really -- you think this represents a professional expert judgment as to what likely reality is?

turn.speaker: francis_x_beytagh_jr
turn.label: Mr. Francis X. Beytagh, Jr.
turn.text: Well, I think that the idea is that when you have a man that's willing to do this much but then you have a more or less stable family unit that does not fit under the category --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: But the experience would show that in the MARS situation it's just contrary to the reality assumingly.

turn.speaker: francis_x_beytagh_jr
turn.label: Mr. Francis X. Beytagh, Jr.
turn.text: I think so, I think that as soon as you try to put an obligation, a real obligation of support on these MARS people at least, their alternative is simply to get out and that California's statute both as to stepfathers and as to MARS provides that they have an obligation of support only when they're in the home, if they leave then they don't have an obligation, it evaporates.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Sure, sure well that's the result of this regulation has been to -- that some MARS have left.
Does that happen in one or two of these cases or why not?

turn.speaker: francis_x_beytagh_jr
turn.label: Mr. Francis X. Beytagh, Jr.
turn.text: I don't know whether it has been the result --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: It must be that the California regulation has some real teeth in the thing.

turn.speaker: francis_x_beytagh_jr
turn.label: Mr. Francis X. Beytagh, Jr.
turn.text: Well, it has real teeth when it deprives people that need support of.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Well, I know that it deprives MARS out of the family must be because there's a real obligation as long as they stay there, then why isn't the statute --

turn.speaker: francis_x_beytagh_jr
turn.label: Mr. Francis X. Beytagh, Jr.
turn.text: No, the reason they don't stay there is because the money is cut off and since their income is assumed to be available but it is not really available because they have other children to support or whatever, then they move out because they are not in fact able to provide support.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: But I think there is another hypothesis for their moving out too and wasn't it one of the considerations in the development of the scheme namely that when they aid to dependent children stopped, the free boarder left because the income stopped.

turn.speaker: francis_x_beytagh_jr
turn.label: Mr. Francis X. Beytagh, Jr.
turn.text: Well --

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: That didn't -- doesn't that show up in the legislative history?

turn.speaker: francis_x_beytagh_jr
turn.label: Mr. Francis X. Beytagh, Jr.
turn.text: Your Honor, I think it shows up in the early legislative history.
In King versus Smith, I think the Court made clear that the notion of punishing the kids by seeking to legislate morality for the mother had been abandoned by Congress in subsequent amendments.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Well, I'm talking about the punishment of the children aspect, I'm talking about what you were addressing yourself to the reasons for the departure of this putative --

turn.speaker: francis_x_beytagh_jr
turn.label: Mr. Francis X. Beytagh, Jr.
turn.text: But to the extent that there is a notion of having stable family units, it seems to me that HEW's approach and not California fosters that because HEW's approach allows the reduction in the amount of benefit payments only when there is proof of actual income and therefore, when there is not actual income the MARS or the stepfather I assume will continue to reside with the children.
Now, to the extent that that's a value worth preserving, HEW's approach preserves, the California's does not.

California forces the man to move out of the house when he doesn't have income that helps support the children so that they won't receive the reduction, it won't be cutoff as to some of the people on this case were.
The reasons that we submitted and the reason stated in the brief, we think the District Court erred and the judgment should be reversed and remanded for further --

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Yeah, but the Supreme Court of California has a chance --

turn.speaker: francis_x_beytagh_jr
turn.label: Mr. Francis X. Beytagh, Jr.
turn.text: Alright.
Your Honor, my understanding is that Supreme Court of California has not had a chance to pass squarely on this.
There's some lower California Appellate Court --

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: You don't know how they would construe their law on the later amendment to it.

turn.speaker: francis_x_beytagh_jr
turn.label: Mr. Francis X. Beytagh, Jr.
turn.text: That correct but I don't think that really the law needs too much construction perhaps counsel from California will illuminate us on this but the intermediate appellate court decision are quite ambiguous.
Frankly, they speak in terms of the obligation of support not being a general one that applies across the board but one tailored to AFDC.
Well, that's quite right it is one tailored to AFDC.
There was a case where one of these people said that this law was a deprivation of his right of property.
California couldn't do this and the Court said no that's not right, he is not being deprived of anything.
He simply -- his income is simply being assumed to have been transferred to the support of the children.
So, to the extent that this California authority, it's confusing and ambiguous but it at least raises questions as to whether the duty of support is anything more than a loser one.
Thank you.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Thank you, Mr.Beytagh.
Mr.Linderman.

turn.speaker: jay_s_linderman
turn.label: Mr. Jay S. Linderman
turn.text: Mr. Chief Justice and may it please the Court.

I might -- I might start Mr. Justice Black in trying to answer your question regarding a determination by the Secretary of HEW of whether California is in compliance and if not, why not cut California off.

When this litigation started in the District Court, California officials were in the process then of trying to determine from HEW whether in fact, HEW felt that the California statute and regulations were in conflict and we were unable to even receive a definitive statement from HEW whether or not the secretary considered California to be in compliance or not.

And we urge the various correspondents on this subject was attached to our motion to dismiss filed in the District Court and we urge the District Court at that time that there is a procedure in the Social Security Act for resolving disputes between the states and HEW as to whether a state plan does or does not comply.
The secretary makes a determination of noncompliance.
The state is given the authority to petition the Court of Appeals for the particular circuit for determination of that specific issue.
We urge the District Court to allow us to do that or at least to first allow us to receive a --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: It allows you to do what now?

turn.speaker: jay_s_linderman
turn.label: Mr. Jay S. Linderman
turn.text: To utilize the procedure set forth --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: State?

turn.speaker: jay_s_linderman
turn.label: Mr. Jay S. Linderman
turn.text: In the Social Security Act provides a procedure for resolving a dispute between the states and HEW.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: What is the --

turn.speaker: jay_s_linderman
turn.label: Mr. Jay S. Linderman
turn.text: What is the procedure?

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: jay_s_linderman
turn.label: Mr. Jay S. Linderman
turn.text: If HEW makes a determination of noncompliance of a state plan, the state may go to the Court of Appeals for the particular circuit in which the state is located.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: May I just interrupt you for a moment.
It has to be formal disapproval about the state plan.

turn.speaker: jay_s_linderman
turn.label: Mr. Jay S. Linderman
turn.text: My understanding Mr. Justice is that it has to be a determination, the languages is a determination that --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Except but it does some kind of a formal determination?

turn.speaker: jay_s_linderman
turn.label: Mr. Jay S. Linderman
turn.text: A -- a formal determination.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: They seek determination.
Is there a hearing, what happens there?

turn.speaker: jay_s_linderman
turn.label: Mr. Jay S. Linderman
turn.text: It -- in California what was happening at the time this suit started was considerable correspondence going back and forth between the governor and the director of the state primary social welfare.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Did he took by correspondent with the state officials and the HEW?

turn.speaker: jay_s_linderman
turn.label: Mr. Jay S. Linderman
turn.text: And the secretary at that time is Secretary Cohen.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: But nothing in the way of a formal proceeding administratively before the board or something like that?

turn.speaker: jay_s_linderman
turn.label: Mr. Jay S. Linderman
turn.text: Nothing at that point because when the suit was filed, California was still in the process of trying to find out whether the secretary had even made a determination that California was not in compliance and then this lawsuit was filed in the middle of it, and we urge the District --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: And we suggested that the review expressly provided that the statute in the appropriate Circuit Court of Appeals, a review of what?

turn.speaker: jay_s_linderman
turn.label: Mr. Jay S. Linderman
turn.text: Of the question of whether the state plan conflicts or conforms.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: But wouldn't have to be reviewed some formal determination sometime?

turn.speaker: jay_s_linderman
turn.label: Mr. Jay S. Linderman
turn.text: I would assume so yes and that is what we were attempting --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: I assume--
(Inaudible) --

turn.speaker: jay_s_linderman
turn.label: Mr. Jay S. Linderman
turn.text: I would assume that it is a written communicate from the Secretary of HEW that, dear Governor --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: For example, would this be the case?
If your California officials had received from HEW a letter which said, we don't think that California plan complies with the federal regulations.
You could have judicial review on the Ninth Circuit of that letter of determination?

turn.speaker: jay_s_linderman
turn.label: Mr. Jay S. Linderman
turn.text: Questionable --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: No, these are compliance proceedings under the statute aren't they?
The HEW as I understand is only proceeded against two states and there's long history of this.
One is Connecticut and the other is Nevada, is that right?

turn.speaker: jay_s_linderman
turn.label: Mr. Jay S. Linderman
turn.text: Yes, Nevada.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Those are compliance proceedings.

turn.speaker: jay_s_linderman
turn.label: Mr. Jay S. Linderman
turn.text: This is --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: They come into -- they come up to adjudication whether they can be reviewed has never been determined.

turn.speaker: jay_s_linderman
turn.label: Mr. Jay S. Linderman
turn.text: I think that's correct but what happened in the California instance was the state director of social welfare did receive a letter from the secretary, then Secretary Cohen setting forth various reasons why the secretary felt that California was not in compliance.

The director from California then wrote back to the secretary and said, “If this is a determination of noncompliance, then we respectfully request reconsideration but please tell us what it is that you are saying” and we never received a reply to that.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Is that correspondence in the appendix here?

turn.speaker: jay_s_linderman
turn.label: Mr. Jay S. Linderman
turn.text: It's not in the correspondence Mr.Justice, it is attached to the motion to dismiss which the state filed in the District Court.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: So that would in the whole record that's here.

turn.speaker: jay_s_linderman
turn.label: Mr. Jay S. Linderman
turn.text: It's in the record but it's not in the appendix.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: And do you have statutory citation to this review procedure to which you refer?

turn.speaker: jay_s_linderman
turn.label: Mr. Jay S. Linderman
turn.text: I believe its Section 1116 of the Social Security Act.
I don't have the US Code citation but it is I believe its Section 1116.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Was it while the state and Federal Government when negotiation with reference to whether or not your state was in compliance that this suit was filed on the part of the led individual beneficiary in California?

turn.speaker: jay_s_linderman
turn.label: Mr. Jay S. Linderman
turn.text: I believe the timing Mr. Justice Black, the correspondence was in the summer of 1968, and the first of these two consolidated cases was filed in October of '68, but as far as the state was concerned, we had never received any definitive statement from the secretary as to whether we were or we're not in compliance when the lawsuit was filed.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Have you ever received ever since --

turn.speaker: jay_s_linderman
turn.label: Mr. Jay S. Linderman
turn.text: Never since, other the appearance of HEW as amicus in this proceeding alleging that we are not in compliance.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Between you and the alleged beneficiaries.

turn.speaker: jay_s_linderman
turn.label: Mr. Jay S. Linderman
turn.text: Pardon me.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: As between California and the alleged beneficiary, that's the lawsuit now?

turn.speaker: jay_s_linderman
turn.label: Mr. Jay S. Linderman
turn.text: Right.
The lawsuit now is the alleged beneficiaries against the state alleging that the state is not in compliance with Federal law.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Has any Court of Appeals has been called upon to act under this procedure?

turn.speaker: jay_s_linderman
turn.label: Mr. Jay S. Linderman
turn.text: To my -- I am not familiar with any Justice --.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: It hardly strikes me as an ideal way to litigate a complex legal questions that go directly on no record from an administrative determination to the Court of Appeals.
At least in all the other administrative reviews by the Court of Appeals there is a complete record.

turn.speaker: jay_s_linderman
turn.label: Mr. Jay S. Linderman
turn.text: I'm not certain that that's anymore improper or inappropriate method than coming directly to the United States Supreme Court to resolve the same question with not much more record.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Well, actually that could be done, couldn't it in quite a different way if the executive branch of the United States of America cutoff a lot in California because you were not in compliance with the conditions under which those funds are made available under these categorical existence program.
California could then sue the United States of America in this Court as a Nisi Prius Court, is that right?

turn.speaker: jay_s_linderman
turn.label: Mr. Jay S. Linderman
turn.text: Yes, I would think so Mr. Justice Stewart.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Well, if United States voted that, do you think the alleged beneficiaries all over the state could sue you?

turn.speaker: jay_s_linderman
turn.label: Mr. Jay S. Linderman
turn.text: Could sue the state?

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Yeah.

turn.speaker: jay_s_linderman
turn.label: Mr. Jay S. Linderman
turn.text: I'm not certain.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: What's the difference with that lawsuit at this point?

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Well, your state could have a Social Security wholly independent of ideal funds?

turn.speaker: jay_s_linderman
turn.label: Mr. Jay S. Linderman
turn.text: Of course, it could but I doubt very much.
I think I can speak for the state.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Not constitutionally speaking.

turn.speaker: jay_s_linderman
turn.label: Mr. Jay S. Linderman
turn.text: Of course, of course but I think I can speak for --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Would it have a right to administer, wouldn't it?

turn.speaker: jay_s_linderman
turn.label: Mr. Jay S. Linderman
turn.text: As it chose, I would think so.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Subject to only the constitutional restrictions.

turn.speaker: jay_s_linderman
turn.label: Mr. Jay S. Linderman
turn.text: Constitutional restrictions would be the only one.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: And as I understand it, there's no one to get challenge.
That there is no constitutional provision which will prevent California from spending its own fund in its own way, if it doesn't mix them up with the federal receipts.

turn.speaker: jay_s_linderman
turn.label: Mr. Jay S. Linderman
turn.text: Well, I think the appellants in this case are arguing that irrespective of the supremacy clause problem in the case that even assuming that there's no problem there that California is distributing its funds in violation of the Equal Protection Clause.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Absolutely and that same argument would be made whether or not to any federal funds.

turn.speaker: jay_s_linderman
turn.label: Mr. Jay S. Linderman
turn.text: Definitely.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: How do they raise it under the Equal Protection?

turn.speaker: jay_s_linderman
turn.label: Mr. Jay S. Linderman
turn.text: Their allegation is that the obligation which California places on MARS in a welfare home only as opposed to a MARS in a non-welfare home denies Equal Protection to the children in the welfare home and to the MARS in the welfare home.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: That would raise a question purely under the state law.

turn.speaker: jay_s_linderman
turn.label: Mr. Jay S. Linderman
turn.text: They are raising the question --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: And you could sue the state --

turn.speaker: jay_s_linderman
turn.label: Mr. Jay S. Linderman
turn.text: They are raising --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: That wouldn't be tied up at all with the Federal Government's position in connection with compliance.

turn.speaker: jay_s_linderman
turn.label: Mr. Jay S. Linderman
turn.text: No, it would --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: As I understand that lawsuit is based on quite a different theory.

turn.speaker: jay_s_linderman
turn.label: Mr. Jay S. Linderman
turn.text: Oh, it is.

But this is an aspect of their lawsuit also as the Equal Protection problem which assuming that California were running its own welfare program, not receiving federal matching funds presumably the same constitutional limitations are going to have to apply.
The only ones that would be eliminated would be the regulations of HEW and the act of Cardozo.

turn.speaker: lewis_f_powell_jr
turn.label: Justice Lewis F. Powell, Jr.
turn.text: I'd suppose that all of these was answered by Cardozo in that initial case in the Stewart Machine Company case back in 1936.
These are the conditions upon which the states would participate, the state need not participate.
They do participate unless -- to get federal funds, they must participate on the federal condition.

turn.speaker: jay_s_linderman
turn.label: Mr. Jay S. Linderman
turn.text: We don't question the fact that California must comply with valid HEW regulations and an act of Congress in order to be able to qualify to receive the federal funds.
We are not disputing that at all.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: And suppose that's -- any question has been raised about that by anybody?

turn.speaker: jay_s_linderman
turn.label: Mr. Jay S. Linderman
turn.text: None whatsoever and nor do we question the authority of the secretary of HEW to issue rules and regulations to fill up the details of the Social Security.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: If state wants to participate it would have to comply.

turn.speaker: jay_s_linderman
turn.label: Mr. Jay S. Linderman
turn.text: No question about it Mr. Justice Black.
Our position however is though that the secretary of HEW in his regulations has exceeded the scope of authority given to him by Congress in the Social Security Act.
We --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: There is no question that that's controversy between that's involved in this case even though the parties of the State of California and the welfare benefit --

turn.speaker: jay_s_linderman
turn.label: Mr. Jay S. Linderman
turn.text: No question that that's the crucial --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: There's no question that that issue is a case of controversy properly before this Court for decision making.

turn.speaker: jay_s_linderman
turn.label: Mr. Jay S. Linderman
turn.text: I would not -- I would conceive that yes.
My point initially was that there is an alternative procedures that the controversy could first be resolved in the Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit.
I don't --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Well, I guess what's you were addressing yourself earlier.

turn.speaker: jay_s_linderman
turn.label: Mr. Jay S. Linderman
turn.text: Exactly.
I assume though that even if that were resolved in the Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit that sooner or later it would reach here.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: But you'd manage to do something somehow?

turn.speaker: jay_s_linderman
turn.label: Mr. Jay S. Linderman
turn.text: Yes.
The HEW regulation has two parts to it.
The first one is the secretary's definition of who maybe a parent which of course goes to the question of is the child a dependent child and eligible or not eligible for assistance.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: At all but that doesn't go to the question of the amount of money, it goes to the question of eligibility at all.

turn.speaker: jay_s_linderman
turn.label: Mr. Jay S. Linderman
turn.text: At all.
If the person is determined to be a parent, there is no eligibility with the exception of the unemployed parent and the optional AFDC --

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Well, with some if you have a chance but generally speaking if both parents are in the house ineligibility.

turn.speaker: jay_s_linderman
turn.label: Mr. Jay S. Linderman
turn.text: By definition, Social Security Act sets up AFDC eligibility for a child who is deprived of parental support because on the absence of a parent.

HEW in subsection A of its regulation 203.1 says that, the only person who can be a parent is a natural father, an adopted father or a stepfather who is legally obligated to support the child to the same extent as a natural or adoptive father.
If that's correct -- now California is not attempting to define children living with a MARS or stepfather as non-dependent children.
We are not trying to call the stepfather or the MARS a parent.
But under HEW's definition, the only thing California did wrong was to limit the stepparent liability to a stepparent in a welfare home.

If California had imposed an obligation on all stepfathers to support their children, then it seems to me that under the HEW regulation, California could determine all needy children in a home with a stepfather totally ineligible for aid and it certainly escapes me how the child -- the needy child in a welfare home derives anymore economic protection from the extension of the stepfather liability to a stepfather in a non-welfare home.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: But if you're right then you are violating the Federal law in a different way because you're spending federal money that you're not authorized to spend because you're giving it to children who are ineligible under the federal statute.

turn.speaker: jay_s_linderman
turn.label: Mr. Jay S. Linderman
turn.text: But we can easily remedy the situation Mr. Justice Stewart by simply exchanging our support obligation statute and making all stepfathers liable for the support of their children.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: As I say if you do that, then if you give any money to a family of the stepfather then you're making an unauthorized expenditure of federal money and you're violating the federal law.

turn.speaker: jay_s_linderman
turn.label: Mr. Jay S. Linderman
turn.text: Which to me would be frustrative of the purposes of AFDC which is to impose a support obligation on a stepfather in a relatively affluent family.
Certainly, it gives no economic protection to the child with a stepfather in a poor family.

It makes no sense but if the HEW regulation is valid, I think I can state with relative certainty that California will just extend its stepfather liability statute and cut off all children in stepfather homes.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: And that in turn will be litigated I assume.

turn.speaker: jay_s_linderman
turn.label: Mr. Jay S. Linderman
turn.text: I would assume.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Well, you won't care about unless the stepfather has an income.

turn.speaker: jay_s_linderman
turn.label: Mr. Jay S. Linderman
turn.text: Assuming an employed stepfather because if you were unemployed then the family would qualify under California's optional AFDCU in the argument.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: You won't cut off anymore children as you are now?

turn.speaker: jay_s_linderman
turn.label: Mr. Jay S. Linderman
turn.text: We are not cutting off children now though Mr. Justice White, we're --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: You are reducing payments by assuming the income of the stepfather.

turn.speaker: jay_s_linderman
turn.label: Mr. Jay S. Linderman
turn.text: We're reducing payments --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Availability --

turn.speaker: jay_s_linderman
turn.label: Mr. Jay S. Linderman
turn.text: Assumed availability because of the support obligation.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Sure, so you reduce the payments on accountability.
One, you wouldn't do it -- you wouldn't cut off anymore if you extend that your obligation is right across the board.

turn.speaker: jay_s_linderman
turn.label: Mr. Jay S. Linderman
turn.text: Some children living with stepfathers are still receiving aid because the stepfather's net income is insufficient to bring the family up to the states' maximum budget for the family.
But if we extend the stepfather liability to non AFDC family stepfathers, then the children in the AFDC family with the stepfathers are going to be totally cutoff.
There are now children in the AFDC stepfather family who are still receiving aid, all be it less aid because of the obligation of support on the --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: What about the MARS?

turn.speaker: jay_s_linderman
turn.label: Mr. Jay S. Linderman
turn.text: It seems to me --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: If your old law, you said you changed it, you put the obligation on him to do so --

turn.speaker: jay_s_linderman
turn.label: Mr. Jay S. Linderman
turn.text: The old -- it still does in a different fashion.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: -- you've modified.

turn.speaker: jay_s_linderman
turn.label: Mr. Jay S. Linderman
turn.text: We've modified it but the statute which was the subject of litigation in the court below, the obligation was that the MARS had to support the children in his home.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Just like the stepfather does.

turn.speaker: jay_s_linderman
turn.label: Mr. Jay S. Linderman
turn.text: Like the stepfather and I would submit that if HEW thinks that you can extend statewide general law of amicability to a stepfather and thereby make no --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Can do it with the man.

turn.speaker: jay_s_linderman
turn.label: Mr. Jay S. Linderman
turn.text: Can do it with the man equally as well and in fact, I would think might have to do it not because of any moral antipathy to the common law marriage but if you don't do it, a man is crazy to marry the welfare mother.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: But what the -- is the MARS issue a live, a real issue here?

turn.speaker: jay_s_linderman
turn.label: Mr. Jay S. Linderman
turn.text: Oh, I think very definitely so.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Because of back payments or what?

turn.speaker: jay_s_linderman
turn.label: Mr. Jay S. Linderman
turn.text: Yes, yes.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Is that all?

turn.speaker: jay_s_linderman
turn.label: Mr. Jay S. Linderman
turn.text: There --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Because the new regulation is not an issue in this suit?

turn.speaker: jay_s_linderman
turn.label: Mr. Jay S. Linderman
turn.text: No yet, there's -- no, it is not an issue in this suit but the same problem, the problem of assuming that there is a meaningful support obligation that's a different kind of obligation now.

But the same question of whether the obligation that California imposes is an enforceable one and a source of a resource to the child will remain even under the new regulation, it will take on different --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Don't you -- wouldn't you suppose though that as a matter of experience you could justify assuming income -- assuming availability of income where the real parent is living at home and have a wholly different experience with stepfathers or MARS who are living in the home, just in terms actual availability of income.

turn.speaker: jay_s_linderman
turn.label: Mr. Jay S. Linderman
turn.text: If your question is directed to the point isn't a natural father more apt to support his child than a stepfather, is that the gist of your question?

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: That's part of it, yes.

turn.speaker: jay_s_linderman
turn.label: Mr. Jay S. Linderman
turn.text: I would say, yes, if the kind of stepfather or the man in the house that California is talking about is the same kind of a man as Alabama had in King versus Smith.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Well, then why isn't the Federal regulation --a valid expression of a -- valid judgment along those lines?

turn.speaker: jay_s_linderman
turn.label: Mr. Jay S. Linderman
turn.text: Because the Federal regulation Mr. Justice White is not geared to the factual realities of who these men are that California is concerned with.
They are not the midnight visitor in King versus Smith who had a family of his own and nine children and no income.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: I would think the invalidity of it might be is it permit the assumption of income or availability of income where there is a statewide law of general applicability if that's contrary to experience.

turn.speaker: jay_s_linderman
turn.label: Mr. Jay S. Linderman
turn.text: I think the Social Security Act compels assumption of income though where there's a law of support.
As this Court interpreted the purposes of AFDC in King versus Smith, it was to provide support for children without -- who could not --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Do you think it would be invalid under the Social Security Act for HEW to provide by regulation that income of natural parents, availability of income or the natural parent living in the home will not be assumed?

turn.speaker: jay_s_linderman
turn.label: Mr. Jay S. Linderman
turn.text: Yes, I think it would be invalid.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Under the statute?

turn.speaker: jay_s_linderman
turn.label: Mr. Jay S. Linderman
turn.text: Under the Social Security Act as interpreted by this Court in King versus Smith.

That Congress expects that when there is a breadwinner in the home that the breadwinner will support the child and the Social Security Act says that the state has to -- the second part of this is that the state has to determine the extent of need of the children in the home and the child is deemed less needy because of the resource which is assumed by Congress in view to the benefit of the child because of the support obligation.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Mr.Linderman, I think you used the term that the assumption was compelled.
Now, that assumption also depends upon the enforceability of the support against this man in the house.
Is that a safe assumption or rational assumption that there is any real enforceability against the man in the house?

turn.speaker: jay_s_linderman
turn.label: Mr. Jay S. Linderman
turn.text: I think there is Mr. Chief Justice.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: How?
By suits against the man?

turn.speaker: jay_s_linderman
turn.label: Mr. Jay S. Linderman
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: How many lawyers is it going to take the deal with the 500,000 people on welfare in Los Angeles alone?

turn.speaker: jay_s_linderman
turn.label: Mr. Jay S. Linderman
turn.text: I appreciate that problem but it's not any different than the child living with a natural father who may not support it.
The child or his mother has to sue the man not the state.
The state doesn't pay aid and then pursue the man.
The child has to get the money from the man.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Does this record show what is the ratio of unemployed natural fathers whose children are receiving this aid as compared with the man in the house type of situation, any information on that at all?

turn.speaker: jay_s_linderman
turn.label: Mr. Jay S. Linderman
turn.text: Unemployed fathers, not that I know of Your Honor.

There are statistics that would indicate how many families we're talking about which contain -- the figures are July 1968 and at that time there were roughly 191,000 families -- AFDC families in California and of that there were 6,700 families with the stepfather and 2,800 families with the MARS.
A total of roughly 9,500 families out of 191,000 families but of the 191,000, I am not familiar with the statistics on how many of those are unemployed fathers.
I could easily obtain them and supply them to the Court if you will.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: I'm not sure if that's necessary unless someone else wants it.
What I'm trying to get at is that this assumption that you are talking about is based on further assumption of the enforceability against this man.

turn.speaker: jay_s_linderman
turn.label: Mr. Jay S. Linderman
turn.text: That's correct and it's the same assumption as applies with a natural father in the home and it's an assumption that there is an enforceability.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: But wouldn't you concede that it is easier to enforce that claim against the natural father by the usual traditional processes that it is against these transient men in the house.

turn.speaker: jay_s_linderman
turn.label: Mr. Jay S. Linderman
turn.text: But Your Honor by definition these men are not transients.
These are --

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: By whose definition?

turn.speaker: jay_s_linderman
turn.label: Mr. Jay S. Linderman
turn.text: By the state definition before the application of the rule even can begin the person -- the man in the house by definition is living in the home and is, in stepfather case, ceremonially married to the mother or in the MARS case is living in the home and has either assumed financial obligations on behalf of the family or comports himself in the community as husband and wife.
And one of the crucial criteria of determining who is the MARS is that he has no other alternative place of residence.
Just as his family and to the extent that he is a trencher the moment he leaves the home the child is restored the eligibility.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Mr. Linderman, do I understand you correctly that the child and the wife have to go to Court to get the support from the husband who left?

turn.speaker: jay_s_linderman
turn.label: Mr. Jay S. Linderman
turn.text: Who has left?

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: jay_s_linderman
turn.label: Mr. Jay S. Linderman
turn.text: They would have to go to Court only to the extent to collect back payments that might be due.
Once the man leaves the house --

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: In the California welfare system, you mean that welfare system doesn't do that?

turn.speaker: jay_s_linderman
turn.label: Mr. Jay S. Linderman
turn.text: Not to collect the back payments.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: You don't have a special department that that's all they do.

turn.speaker: jay_s_linderman
turn.label: Mr. Jay S. Linderman
turn.text: Not for the MARS or the stepfather.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: No, no I said for the legitimate father.

turn.speaker: jay_s_linderman
turn.label: Mr. Jay S. Linderman
turn.text: For the legitimate father, yes.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: So you go after him to make him pay his debts.

turn.speaker: jay_s_linderman
turn.label: Mr. Jay S. Linderman
turn.text: After he leaves the house.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: After he leaves his house.

turn.speaker: jay_s_linderman
turn.label: Mr. Jay S. Linderman
turn.text: After he leaves the house but not one of his --

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: I thought you said the responsibility was upon the children?

turn.speaker: jay_s_linderman
turn.label: Mr. Jay S. Linderman
turn.text: While the man is in the house.
While the man is in the house be he a natural father or adoptive father or stepfather or MARS, the state does not pursue his resources for the child.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Even if the wife applies for relief?

turn.speaker: jay_s_linderman
turn.label: Mr. Jay S. Linderman
turn.text: If the wife applies for relief in the natural father case and he is living in the home, relief is denied, they are ineligible by definition.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: The minute he leaves, the welfare makes him pay if they find that he has the money.

turn.speaker: jay_s_linderman
turn.label: Mr. Jay S. Linderman
turn.text: If they can find it.
But with MARS, the state does not pursue it because there's no more obligation and the state pays aid at that point in time.

The other one important resource which I think is unique in the West, particularly in California, in the case of the stepfather is that under California community property law, the earnings of the stepfather are community property in which the wife, the welfare mother has a vested present one-half interest.
Half of his earnings are hers.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: That's with the ceremonial marriage.

turn.speaker: jay_s_linderman
turn.label: Mr. Jay S. Linderman
turn.text: That's what the stepfather only.
Yes, after the ceremonial marriage, there is no community property in a putative marriage.
There is in a meretricious -- in the putative there is, in a meretricious there is not.
In other words, these people know they are not married, the MARS and the mother and there is no community property there.
If one of them harbors the mistake and belief that they are married, there can be community property there.
But I'm talking about the situation where the mother has ceremonially married the man.
Community property then attaches to his earnings, and half of his earnings are hers.
I would submit that if there is anything that is a resource which the Social Security Act commands California to consider in determining need, that is a resource.
Again, the mother may have to take legal action to protect her half interest, but that's no different than the mother living with the natural father of her children.
She also may have to take legal recourse but the obligation is clearly enforceable.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: What specific language in the Social Security Act do you rely on for arguing that the Federal regulation is invalid?

turn.speaker: jay_s_linderman
turn.label: Mr. Jay S. Linderman
turn.text: Section 402(a)(7) which is 42 U. S. C., Section 602(a)(7).

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Do you have that in appendix to your --

turn.speaker: jay_s_linderman
turn.label: Mr. Jay S. Linderman
turn.text: Yes, it appears at several places.
It's in the appendix -- it's cited throughout all the briefs.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: I wanted a quick easy place where we can find it.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: What is the specific language?

turn.speaker: jay_s_linderman
turn.label: Mr. Jay S. Linderman
turn.text: I read the language.
The place is the first page of the appendix in the Government's brief.
This is Section 602(a)(7).

It's one of the series of requirements of the Social Security Act as to what state plan must provide and says that a state plan for aid and services to needy families with children must, underscore must, provide that the state shall in determining need take into consideration any other income and resources of any child or relative claiming aid.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: We're talking about income and resources.

turn.speaker: jay_s_linderman
turn.label: Mr. Jay S. Linderman
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Now, you are saying that the emphasis of that act have a regulation says that income and sources are not going to be assumed.

turn.speaker: jay_s_linderman
turn.label: Mr. Jay S. Linderman
turn.text: Exactly.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: That the statute requires that you assume that was Social Security?

turn.speaker: jay_s_linderman
turn.label: Mr. Jay S. Linderman
turn.text: Not assumed.
No, no, our position --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: You're talking about income and resources of the child.

turn.speaker: jay_s_linderman
turn.label: Mr. Jay S. Linderman
turn.text: Yes, of the child or the mother.
See, it's income and resources of any child or relative claiming aid.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: And who's claiming aid?

turn.speaker: jay_s_linderman
turn.label: Mr. Jay S. Linderman
turn.text: The mother and the child.
That's the child or the mother.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: So you've got to say that income don't have to assume the availability of income from the MARS and stepfather.
Either to the mother of the child.
You said that Act requires that.
Whether it's a MARS in the house or stepfather in the house and the state has legal obligation that this Act requires that you assume that that income is available to the child.

turn.speaker: jay_s_linderman
turn.label: Mr. Jay S. Linderman
turn.text: Assume that it is available because it is a resource.
It's something in addition to prove an income.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Although, it is the natural resource must be factual.

turn.speaker: jay_s_linderman
turn.label: Mr. Jay S. Linderman
turn.text: But neither is the resource of the child living with a natural father.
The natural father may not --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: That is the point for you and I would make the same argument that perhaps the HEW did say that it is the parent living in the house as I am going to assume.

turn.speaker: jay_s_linderman
turn.label: Mr. Jay S. Linderman
turn.text: As this Court pointed out in King versus Smith, if there is a legal obligation of support, proof of actual contribution cannot be determinative.
That's the language --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: They may not be determinative of the -- you pick the regulation which requires proof of active contribution as invalid to --.

turn.speaker: jay_s_linderman
turn.label: Mr. Jay S. Linderman
turn.text: Yes, because it defines a child in California to be resourceless.
The child can have nothing other than the income that the state through some administrative miracle can --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: As far as regularly and definitely, that would be the excuse to contribute anything to the support the child regardless of the legal obligation for him imposed by the state, is that what you were saying?

turn.speaker: jay_s_linderman
turn.label: Mr. Jay S. Linderman
turn.text: No, but the mother will undoubtedly kick the man out of the house.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: That's another assumption.

turn.speaker: jay_s_linderman
turn.label: Mr. Jay S. Linderman
turn.text: But it is a weapon.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: That's not very relevant for a legal --

turn.speaker: jay_s_linderman
turn.label: Mr. Jay S. Linderman
turn.text: I think it is Mr. Justice White.
It's a weapon.
It's a method of enforcement of the obligation that the state is reducing the grant and the mother can say with real meaning support me or get out.
And the facts of this case, the complaints in this case despite their protestations that the men are not supporting the children in the house.

The complainants themselves admit that due to the emergency as the language that the plaintiff appellant used that due to the emergency caused by this state statute, the men are supporting the children until the statute is declared invalid.
The statute does work, it is enforceable and the men are supporting the children at least some of the names plaintiffs are and the record will show that.
The other fact is that in the case of the stepfather and presumably in the MARS as well.
It's literally impossible for them not to support them at least in some of these cases where the man has taken the welfare mother and her children into his home.
He has put a roof over their head which is the case in several of the named plaintiffs in this appeal.
The man has brought the children into his home.
Now, certainly to some extent, he is putting a roof over their head which is a lessened need for public expense to support that family.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: California does have a maximum grant regulation, does it not?

turn.speaker: jay_s_linderman
turn.label: Mr. Jay S. Linderman
turn.text: Under challenge.
Yes, it does have a maximum grant and the case has been argued before this Court.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
